docs.lead_paragraph: Disconcerting forecasts showing aging populations and increasing burdens on social services are weighing on governments throughout the region.

headline.main: Sex Education in Europe Turns to Urging More Births
headline.print_headline: New Topic in Europe’s Sex-Ed Classrooms: Making More Babies

docs.abstract: Many European countries, anxious about low birth rates, have shifted topics of sex-education classes from safe sex to ways of getting pregnant; United Nations projects that ratio of people over 65 to those of prime working age--20 to 64--will increase globally in next 40 years, adversely affecting economic growth and burdening public pension systems.
docs.snippet: Disconcerting forecasts showing aging populations and increasing burdens on social services are weighing on governments throughout the region.

docs.lead_paragraph: Swedish Match will try to persuade the agency and its experts that traditional smoking warnings are too harsh to describe its product, snus.

headline.main: Swedish Company Asks F.D.A. to Remove Warnings From Smokeless Tobacco Product
headline.print_headline: A Bid for Relief on Tobacco Warning

docs.abstract: Swedish tobacco company Swedish Match hopes to convince Food and Drug Administration that snus, smokeless tobacco product popular in Sweden, is less harmful than cigarettes and should not be labeled with same harsh health warnings; if successful, decision could fundamentally change tobacco regulation in United States.
docs.snippet: Swedish Match will try to persuade the agency and its experts that traditional smoking warnings are too harsh to describe its product, snus.

docs.lead_paragraph: Only half of countries have achieved a global target of getting all children into primary school by 2015, some 58 million youngsters are still getting no education at all, but more girls are going to school, the United Nations said on Thursday.

headline.main: Half of Countries Miss 2015 Goal of Primary Schooling for All: UNESCO
headline.print_headline: Half of Countries Miss 2015 Goal of Primary Schooling for All: UNESCO

docs.snippet: Only half of countries have achieved a global target of getting all children into primary school by 2015, some 58 million youngsters are still getting no education at all, but more girls are going to school, the United Nations said on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: A major U.N. review of global progress on meeting key education targets by 2015 was published on Thursday. Here is a report card on some of the countries working hardest and those failing to make the grade.

headline.main: Factbox: Winners and Losers in the Race to Get Children Into School
headline.print_headline: Factbox: Winners and Losers in the Race to Get Children Into School

docs.snippet: A major U.N. review of global progress on meeting key education targets by 2015 was published on Thursday. Here is a report card on some of the countries working hardest and those failing to make the grade.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two people have been arrested in what authorities describe as a twisted, gruesome case of abuse involving a child's corpse hidden in a broken-down car, a starved baby living on water and a sheltered teenager impregnated by her stepfather.

headline.main: Man, Woman Arrested After Corpse, Severely Abused Kids Found
headline.print_headline: Man, Woman Arrested After Corpse, Severely Abused Kids Found

docs.snippet: Two people have been arrested in what authorities describe as a twisted, gruesome case of abuse involving a child's corpse hidden in a broken-down car, a starved baby living on water and a sheltered teenager impregnated by her stepfather.

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill proposed in the Alabama Legislature could end up banning most abortions if approved, although prospects for passage this year are uncertain.

headline.main: Bill Would Ban Abortions After a Fetal Heartbeat Is Detected
headline.print_headline: Bill Would Ban Abortions After a Fetal Heartbeat Is Detected

docs.snippet: A bill proposed in the Alabama Legislature could end up banning most abortions if approved, although prospects for passage this year are uncertain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials agreed Wednesday to pay $3.5 million to settle a lawsuit that alleged metro Phoenix's sheriff botched the investigation into the rape of a 13-year-old girl and failed to arrest the suspect who then went on to sexually attack her again.

headline.main: Botched Rape Investigation Leads to Major Lawsuit Settlement
headline.print_headline: Botched Rape Investigation Leads to Major Lawsuit Settlement

docs.snippet: Officials agreed Wednesday to pay $3.5 million to settle a lawsuit that alleged metro Phoenix's sheriff botched the investigation into the rape of a 13-year-old girl and failed to arrest the suspect who then went on to sexually attack her again.

docs.lead_paragraph: Oklahoma would ban a common second-trimester abortion procedure that critics describe as dismembering a fetus under a measure that lawmakers overwhelmingly approved Wednesday, a day after Kansas became the first state to prohibit the same procedure.

headline.main: Oklahoma Approves Ban on Second-Trimester Abortion Method
headline.print_headline: Oklahoma Approves Ban on Second-Trimester Abortion Method

docs.snippet: Oklahoma would ban a common second-trimester abortion procedure that critics describe as dismembering a fetus under a measure that lawmakers overwhelmingly approved Wednesday, a day after Kansas became the first state to prohibit the same procedure.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Tennessee state senator says a vasectomy is a "more stringent" medical procedure than an abortion.

headline.main: Tenn. Senator Says Vasectomy 'More Stringent' Than Abortion
headline.print_headline: Tenn. Senator Says Vasectomy 'More Stringent' Than Abortion

docs.snippet: A Tennessee state senator says a vasectomy is a "more stringent" medical procedure than an abortion.

headline.main: Mothers’ Exercise May Lower Heart Risks in Newborns

docs.abstract: Exercise in mice substantially lessened the risk that a pregnant mother-to-be will give birth to offspring with serious heart defects.
docs.snippet: Exercise in mice substantially lessened the risk that a pregnant mother-to-be will give birth to offspring with serious heart defects.
